posts.cooked: Team is currently looking to buy a laptop for drive and software. Our first time having this many robots working at once (previous years) and looking to buy another drive laptop to support driving multiple robots at a time. Would like for it to support drive station and be able to deploy code. Budget is 300-700, but would be willing to invest more for a long term food computer. Need it to be Windows, and have traditionally used Thinkpads in the past.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: I’ll never not suggest the framework 13 because I really want it as our team’s drive station. However I do think it’s a bit over $700

posts.name: Pat Mattin
posts.cooked: I’d look for any refurbished durable laptop. Lots of businesses use them and replace them after a few years. Don’t need something new or fancy, just anything with at least a mid-tier processor, lots of ports, a SSD, made in the past 5 years or so. We have a Dell Rugged, not sure what the exact spec is, but I’m sure that any other brand would be fine.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
I’m personally a fan of the ASUS TUF series of laptops . The line has good performance for just about any Driver Station, Programming, or CAD uses you could throw at it, at an extremely reasonable price. It lacks a lot of the bloatware that’s common on most mainstream laptops, and is probably one of the most durable laptops you can get outside of something actually ruggedized like a Toughbook (lord knows I’ve put mine through a lot). I’ve bought several of these over the years for various uses and they’ve all been rock-solid. They’re also easy to upgrade, whether it be RAM or Storage (the larger laptops often include empty slots to add storage too).

Beyond that, MSI makes decent hardware but it’s generally at a higher price point. Acer is more of a budget-oriented brand but I’ve seen mixed reviews from people I’ve known that have had them.

In general I avoid the “Big Brand” manufacturers like HP, Dell, and Lenovo, as their consumer brands are typically overpriced, under-spec’d, and loaded with bloat. That said, if you can find a good deal on their Business class laptops, you can usually get some decent hardware.

posts.name: Riley Brewer
posts.cooked:
We just bought a ThinkPad T14. The biggest selling points were:

Built-in Ethernet

4 USB ports

Great Battery life

Good build quality

Discount through my employer

We’re satisfied with the screen size, but it’s reasonable to want something larger. We’d love to make our driver station do really cool CUDA accelerated coprocessing . But that’s not on our timeline at all right now, so a beefy NVIDIA GPU wasn’t important.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
To echo what I have recommended in the past .

Any of the Enterprise Class laptops from Lenovo or Dell (ThinkPad or Latitude) are great. You’ll want something with physical ethernet and extra USB ports, Ethernet dongles and USB Hubs just add another point of failure.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.name: Electra Lucky Norwood
posts.cooked:
Govdeals.

Seriously, you can snag some good bulk deals on there and thats where a lot of electronics refurbishing businesses get their stock from.

posts.name: Riley Brewer
posts.cooked:
ElectraLucky5413:

Govdeals.

A lot of the laptops here are “business-class” which is generally what you want.

Another source is WisetekMarket . The company I work (and others) allows employees to buy used corporate computers from this site. After a period of time passes, devices that haven’t sold are made available for the public to buy.

posts.name: Chris_Elston
posts.cooked:
I am a pretty big fan of Thinkpad “P” series laptops. We have a P15 with SSD hard drive. They have lots of USB-C ports, a couple of USB, they support a DOCK, which adds more ports.

https://www.lenovo.com/us/outletus/en/p/laptops/thinkpad/thinkpadp/thinkpad-p15-mobile-workstation/20sux00100

This Docking Station: HOWEVER WARNING…you need 110 VAC to make anything work that is plugged into the dock, like extra HDMI TVs, etc…

https://www.lenovo.com/us/en/p/accessories-and-software/docking/docking_thunderbolt-docks/40b00135us

There are smaller docks you can get as well that powers from the USB-C port but you just need to watch how much power you are pulling.

https://www.lenovo.com/us/en/p/accessories-and-software/docking/docking-usb-docks/40b90000us

Used Thinkpad T series and HP EliteBooks (any business class laptop) are soooo nice for FRC . You can get such good deals on used machines and even on the Lenovo outlet. We’ve been purchasing used off-lease business laptops for our FRC team and will definitely continue into the future. My main requirement lately has been USB C ports and charging, and rj45 connectors.

I agree above on Framework but they can be pricey.

posts.name: Derek W.
posts.cooked: This what we’ve gotten in the past. Microcenter usually has good deals on gaming laptops which seem to work for us.

posts.name: Christopher Ely
posts.cooked: I also reccomend Thinkpads or similar business laptops. They tend to be built better, have more ports, and be more repairable than consumer models. We bought several of these Thinkpad T14s last year for our programmers. We accidentally fried the Ethernet port on one of them (don’t passive PoE your laptops). Replacing it was a ~$30 part and a few screws.

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked: Refurbished Business Class Laptops, such as the Thinkpad T-Series or HP/Dell equivalents.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked:
I think any solid computer is fine.

I am not sure I understand the request “support driving multiple robots at a time”. You can only drive one computer at a time, and the Drive Station software is the same for all of them. Also, deploying is really simple, as long as you install the WPILib tools.

So, I would at least 8th gen Intel or equivalent AMD (so that it supports Win 11), 16 GB RAM (min), and a decent SSD (256 or larger).  Also, if at all possible, make sure it has built in Ethernet (but I have had trouble with “pop-down” Ethernet ports, so avoid if you can).

I am a fan of buying lease return Thinkpads on eBay. Pick a vendor who sells a lot, and make sure the listing uses actual pictures of the unit.

posts.name: Levi
posts.cooked: Going to add on with the thinkpad recommendation. We purchased one when I started which was used while I was a driver as both our driverstation and programming laptop. The only thing I will point out is that thinkpads seem to have a weird driver issue with the batteries where sometimes they will bluescreen on boot (affected all of ours to varying degrees). So if you get one, dont be alarmed just reboot it and you should be good.
